text:
62-61-60-59 Washington Square South, between West Broadway and Thompson Street. No. 61 is noted for having been during 1911-12 the home of the twenty-four year old poet Alan Seegar, who fell on a French battlefield in 1916. The tablet shown on the building was affixed in 1921. Stephen Crane and Frank Norris have also lived in this house; the latter is supposed to have written "The Pit" here. 59-60, together with 58 Washington Square, the old frame house on the corner of Thompson Street, are to be demolished not long after 1925. About 1923.

Neg. # 586, Slide # 140
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - West Broadway

text:
Washington Square South, east from Thompson Street to West Broadway. 58 Washington Square South is the old frame on the corner of Thompson Street. This, with the three small buildings adjoining on Thompson Street, and the two 4-story houses 59-60 Washington Square, are shortly to be demolished. The vacant lot will be fenced about, and later used for tennis courts. June, 1925.

 Neg. # 589
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Thompson Street

text:
248 to 240 Thompson Street and 58, 59 Washington Square South, at, adjoining, and south of the S.E. corner, shortly before the demolition of these buildings. No. 58 Washington Square South, at the corner, and No. 246 Thompson Street, the next door but one below it, are old frame houses. See also Washington Square. No. 240 is the one-story garage adjoining the seven-story building (which will not be torn down) at the N.E. corner of West 3rd Street. August 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Thompson Street - Washington Square South

text:
Washington Square South, from West Broadway to Thompson Street, after demolition of 58-60 Washington Square on and adjoining the corner of Thompson Street. No. 61, next to the clearing, is the house where the poet Alan Seegar once lived. May 24, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - West Broadway

title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.

text:
(1)
Judson Memorial Baptist Church and other buildings, Washington Square South, from Thompson to Sullivan Streets.
This church, with the 7-story tower, was erected in 1892, on the site where a coal-yard had stood in the 1850's. The buildings in the middle of the block, including the rooms in the tower were the Judson Hotel, one of the three Knott hotels on the Square; but they are now a New York University dormitory.
May 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, three weeks later. Notice how the leaves on the trees have come out.
May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A more inclusive view, across the Park.

P. L. Sperr.

December 24, 1935.

THE NEW YORK
PUBLIC LIBRARY

ASTOR LENOX

title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.

text:
Art Exhibition, Washington Square South at the S.E. corner of Thompson Street, seen from Thompson Street, with the Washington Arch, 11-13 Washington Square North, and the One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel, in the background.
The vacant lot results from the demolition of 58 (the old frame house) and 59-60 Washington Square South, about 1927. It will later be used for tennis courts.
This outdoor art exhibition is an annual Greenwich Village event.
May 28, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Thompson Street

text:
Washington Square Park: The circle and Arch as viewed northward from Washington Square South (foreground, car tracks thereon) at Thompson Street and showing on the far side of the Park several 3½-story homes that bear Nos. 13 to 9 Washington Square North. They are the property of the Sailors Snug Harbor Corporation and are east of Fifth Ave.; a thoroughfare that begins at that point. Upon the latter appears the towered apartment house; known as No. 1 Fifth Ave. This is a set of 3 similar views, at different dates.

May 23, 1933.
View 2: May 22, 1935.
View 3: September 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

VIEW 1 B3 - NEG #3768

P. L. Sperr.
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.

text:
Washington Square South (from left to right), south side, west from but not including West Broadway, to and including Thompson Street, showing the clearance at the S.E. corner of Thompson Street created by the demolition of Nos. 60, 59 and 58, and No. 61 (3½-story house with white doorway) which is the Alan Seeger House. Also shown (right) is Thompson Street, west side, from Washington Square South, to and including West 3rd Street, with a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated line on the latter, and the Judson Memorial Church (Baptist) at the S.W. corner of Thompson Street. Note the Alan Seeger Memorial Tree as seen from a point in Washington Square Park.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Supplement:
No. 61 is commonly known as the House of Genius in which lived Theodore Dreiser and Eugene O'Neill, besides the individuals enumerated above. The former lays part of the plot of his famous novel "The Genius" in this house. In the Fall of 1939, this structure is being vacated as the owner finds continued operation unprofitable, and various plans are being suggested.
